comment._content: The Heavy Cruiser looks like either HMAS Canberra or HMAS Australia.

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: The Kalang and Koondooloo were made obsolete as car ferries, following the opening of the Sydney Harbour Bridge in 1932, and eventually converted to Harbour Showboats, immediately popular with the public , Kalang later renamed the 'Sydney Queen'. For their chequered history and sad demise, see: www.ferriesofsydney.com/kalang.html

HMAS CANBERRA (D33) - upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ea/HMAS_Canberra... HMAS AUSTRALIA (D84) - upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0e/HMAS_Australi... (Beware large hi-res files) Anyone know what the ship being tugged is?

comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ah, my friend, they are 2 great photos of HMAS Canberra (I) and HMAS Australia (II) you have referenced there.

However, HMAS Canberra did carry aircraft from time to time:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/3836944674/]

and

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/4823197371/sizes/o/]

Also, good spotting on the crow's nest.  HMAS Australia (II) did not have one for all her service.  Here is a pre World War II photo, without the 'nest:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/6439561431/]

So, I'm still not sure how to vote on the identity of the Heavy Cruiser.

comment.author: 39967544@N00
comment._content:
Another wonderful photo - thanks so much for publishing it! A great atmospheric scene of harbour life and working vessels.
The ferries and the RAN vessels at anchor have been detailed in varying extent by others.
The liner being assisted to its berth (it could be in Walsh Bay or Circular Quay) is Burns Philp's ss Mataram, completed in Glasgow in 1909 for the Company's service between Australia's East Coast ports and Singapore via several harbours in the Dutch East Indies (now Indonesia) and sometimes Port Moresby. When newer ships took over the premier service, Mataram served on Burns Philp's New Guinea and Pacific Island services until its retirement in 1934. Sold to the Japanese for scrap in 1935, the ship in fact served in Chinese and Japanese waters until it was torpedoed early in 1943.

comment.author: 39967544@N00
comment._content: Both HMAS Australia and Canberra were completed and commissioned into the the RAN in 1928, and the opening of the Sydney Harbour Bridge in March 1932 caused the withdrawal of the vehicular ferries for conversion. The photo would have been taken during these years.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39967544@N00] Thanks for the MATARAM id. A couple more images of her - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an5944966 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=456260# A Trove search for "MATARAM" around 1930 does not produce anything helpful for dates, as she visited every few weeks (mostly at Wharf 10 Walsh Bay). Hmmm ...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Our Navy Curator agrees with you Bob - likely to be HMAS CANBERRA but not enough to put money on it! Did find a similar pic though, possibly from the same time. The vessel has awning at the back but no crane. Other thoughts were (due to the crane that is visible) that it might be the same time as this image (1931) of children having a ride in a crate on CANBERRA.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I called upon an expert for an opinion on the identity of the RAN Heavy Cruisers. My friend Mackenzie (Mac) Gregory who served as a junior officer in both HMAS Canberra and HMAS Australia can be considered an expert. In response to my query he writes: "Canberra's wheelhouse had round windows, but in Australia they were square, so that is the basic difference between the two RAN cruisers. The picture I think depicts Canberra. " Mac's blog AHOY is a hub for information on naval history. Find it here: ahoy.tk-jk.net/index.html

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Thanks Bob great stuff! It's great to have so many expert opinions. We have added this to the growing list of info on this image in our database.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 52706710@N03
comment._content: Both Canberra and Australia carried aircraft (Supermarine Seagull), the catapult not being fitted until 1936/37, when the aircraft changed (to Supermarine Walrus). The crane was on the starboard side and folded downwards when out of use. It can be seen in the 1932 photo of Canberra above, but not in the undated 34840 photo of her, so perhaps this is even earlier (although the round base for the catapult can clearly be seen in the latter photo). These 1930s photos (one pre-1937, the other from 1937). Australia Canberra Suggest that although both ships had round wheelhouse windows, Australia had the star from her crest on the face of the bridge and also a crow's nest at this time, as mentioned above. So I'd plump for Canberra also.
